summary: This is an email chain between prosecutors in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York discussing whether to include photos of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein in an indictment for use at a press conference. The discussion references a prior case and Epstein's own press conference.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'GM' in the email chain; prosecutors are discussing including a photo of her with Jeffrey Epstein in an indictment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'JE' in the email chain; prosecutors reference a photo of him with Ghislaine Maxwell and note a prior press conference featuring his photo.

connections.description: Prosecutors refer to an 'iconic' photo of them together, indicating their public association in the context of the criminal case.

events.title: Prosecutor Discussion on Indictment Photos
events.description: Prosecutors in the SDNY discuss via email whether to include photos of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and locations of abuse, in an indictment to use at a press conference.

events.title: Epstein's Press Conference
events.description: Referenced in the email as a prior instance where a photo of Jeffrey Epstein was used at a press conference without being in the indictment.

events.title: The 'Horse Case'
events.description: A prior case referenced by a prosecutor where photos were included in an indictment specifically to use them in a press conference.

keyFacts: Prosecutors in the SDNY were actively planning the indictment and press strategy for Ghislaine Maxwell in June 2020.
The discussion centered on the tactical use of visual evidence, specifically an 'iconic' photo of Maxwell and Epstein together, in legal and public relations contexts.
The email references a prior case (the 'horse case') as a precedent for embedding photos in an indictment to facilitate their use at a press conference.
The correspondence shows prosecutorial awareness of the public nature of the Maxwell/Epstein imagery and its potential impact.
